33.description: A major plantation crop in tropical regions, providing food, oil, fiber, and a wide range of by-products. Known as the 'Tree of Life' in the Philippines.
33.duration: 6–10 years for full yield; productive up to 60 years.
varieties: Dwarf (Tacunan Green Dwarf, Malayan Yellow Dwarf)
33.soilClimate: Thrives in humid tropical climate with 27–32°C temperature. Prefers well-drained sandy loam with pH 5.5–7.5.
33.season: Plant anytime with adequate rainfall; best at onset of rainy season.
33.materials: Use healthy, early-bearing seedlings from certified seed farms.
33.mainField: Plant at 8–9 m spacing in triangular or square system. Provide irrigation and intercrops in early years.
33.weedControl: Regular ring weeding around palm base. Mulching helps retain soil moisture.
33.irrigation: Irrigate young palms every 7–10 days during dry season.
33.growthManagement: Apply organic manure and fertilizers twice yearly. Control rhinoceros beetle and red palm weevil.
33.harvesting: Harvest mature nuts every 45–60 days. Copra or fresh nuts processed depending on purpose.

34.description: A perennial plantation crop cultivated for its beans used in beverages. Grown widely in highland and mid-elevation areas.
34.duration: Productive bearing starts at 3–4 years; economic life 20–30 years.
34.soilClimate: Requires cool climate (18–24°C) with rainfall 1,500–2,500 mm/year. Prefers well-drained loamy soil, pH 6.0–6.5.
34.season: Plant at onset of rainy season (May–July).
34.materials: Use vigorous seedlings from disease-free mother plants.
34.mainField: Plant at 2.5×2.5 m spacing under partial shade. Prune for shape and airflow.
34.weedControl: Weed basins around trees 3–4 times a year.
34.irrigation: Water during dry months to prevent flower drop.
34.growthManagement: Apply organic compost annually. Control coffee rust and berry borer.
34.harvesting: Harvest red ripe berries by hand-picking. Dry, hull, and sort beans for market.

35.description: A tropical plantation crop grown for its beans, used in making chocolate and cocoa products.
35.duration: Fruiting begins 3–4 years after planting; productive life 25–30 years.
35.soilClimate: Thrives in warm, humid climates (25–30°C) with rainfall over 1,200 mm/year. Prefers deep, loamy soil with pH 6.0–7.5.
35.season: Plant at start of rainy season.
35.materials: Use grafted seedlings from high-yielding varieties. Provide shade trees.
35.mainField: Plant at 3×3 m spacing with shade crops. Maintain weed-free basins.
35.weedControl: Manual weeding 3–4 times yearly or mulching to suppress weeds.
35.irrigation: Provide light irrigation during dry months to maintain moisture.
35.growthManagement: Regular pruning, fertilizer application, and pest control. Monitor pod borer and black pod disease.
35.harvesting: Harvest mature pods every 15 days. Ferment, dry, and store beans properly.

36.description: A major industrial crop used for sugar and ethanol production. Also serves as raw material for vinegar and biofuel industries.
36.soilClimate: Grows best in tropical climate (25–35°C) with deep, fertile loam soil and pH 6.0–8.0.
36.season: Plant during dry months (October–February) for rainfed, or anytime for irrigated fields.
36.materials: Use healthy cane setts (3–4 buds) from disease-free mother stalks.
36.mainField: Prepare well-tilled land. Plant setts in furrows 1.2 m apart, 5–10 cm deep.
36.weedControl: Weed at 30, 60, and 90 days after planting or use pre-emergence herbicides.
36.irrigation: Irrigate every 10–15 days during dry season.
36.growthManagement: Apply nitrogen-rich fertilizers and organic manure. Control stem borers and smut disease.
36.harvesting: Harvest when stalks are mature (10–14 months). Cut close to ground level for ratooning.

37.description: A high-value plantation crop grown for its edible oil extracted from fruit pulp and kernel, used in food and industry.
37.duration: Begins bearing 3–4 years after planting; economic life up to 25 years.
37.soilClimate: Requires warm climate (24–32°C) and well-drained deep loamy soil, pH 4.5–6.5.
37.season: Plant at onset of rains for best establishment.
37.materials: Use hybrid tenera seedlings from certified nurseries.
37.mainField: Plant at 9×9 m triangular spacing. Maintain good drainage channels.
37.weedControl: Manual or chemical weeding in basins. Mulch to prevent erosion.
37.irrigation: Supplemental irrigation during prolonged dry spells.
37.growthManagement: Apply balanced fertilizer annually. Control rhinoceros beetle and leaf miner pests.
37.harvesting: Harvest ripe fruit bunches every 10–14 days once trees start bearing.

1.stepProcedure: Purchase rice seeds from any gardening or farmers supply store.

3.stepProcedure: Gather at least 1 to 2 ounces (28.5 to 56.5 g) of rice seeds to sow. Soak the seeds in water to prep them for planting. Allow them to soak for at least 12 hours but not longer than 36 hours. Remove the seeds from the water afterward.

4.stepProcedure: Plant the rice seeds throughout the soil, during the fall or spring season. Get rid of the weeds, till the beds, and level the soil. If you are using buckets, fill them with at least 6 inches (15 cm) of moist soil. Then add the rice seeds.

5.stepProcedure: Fill the buckets or the garden space with at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) of water.

6.stepProcedure: Thin, or space out, the rice seeds to prevent crowding. For best results, thin out the seedlings no more than 4 inches (10.2 cm) apart in rows that range between 9 to 12 inches (22.9 to 30.5 cm) apart. Allow the seeds to grow up to 7 inches (17.8 cm) tall, which takes on average of about one month.

7.stepProcedure: Wait for the rice grains to mature.
